statements.name: PROC CNTSELECT
statements.description: The CNTSELECT (count regression) procedure analyzes regression models in which the dependent variable takes nonnegative integer or count values. The dependent variable is usually an event count, which refers to the number of times an event occurs. For example, an event count might represent the number of ship accidents per year for a given fleet.

arguments.name: CORRB
arguments.description: Prints the correlation matrix of the parameter estimates.

arguments.name: COVB
arguments.description: Prints the covariance matrix of the parameter estimates.

arguments.name: COVEST=
arguments.description: Specifies the type of covariance matrix for the parameter estimates.

arguments.name: OP
arguments.description: Specifies the covariance from the outer product matrix.

arguments.name: HESSIAN
arguments.description: Specifies the covariance from the Hessian matrix.

arguments.name: QML
arguments.description: Specifies the covariance from the outer product and Hessian matrices

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: Specifies the input SAS data set. If the DATA= option is not specified, PROC CMDC uses the most recently created SAS data set.

arguments.name: GROUPID=
arguments.description: specifies an identification variable when a panel data model is estimated. The identification variable is used as a cross-sectional ID variable.

arguments.name: MAXFUNC=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of function calls in the optimization process. The default is 1,000.

arguments.name: MAXITER=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of iterations in the optimization process. The default value is 200.

arguments.name: MAXTIME=
arguments.description: Specifies an upper limit of r seconds of CPU time for the optimization process. The default value is the largest floating-point double representation of your computer. The time specified by this option is checked only once at the end of each iteration. Therefore, the actual running time can be much longer than r. The actual running time includes the remaining time needed to finish the iteration and the time needed to generate the output of the results.

arguments.name: METHOD=
arguments.description: Specifies the iterative minimization method to use. The default is METHOD=NEWRAP.
arguments.help: METHOD=CONGRA | DBLDOG | NONE | NEWRAP | NRRIDG | QUANEW | TRUREG

arguments.name: CONGRA
arguments.description: Specifies a conjugate-gradient method

arguments.name: DBLDOG
arguments.description: Specifies the double dogleg method

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Specifies that no optimization be performed beyond using the ordinary least squares method to compute the parameter estimates.

arguments.name: NEWRAP
arguments.description: Specifies the Newton-Raphson method (this is the default).

arguments.name: NRRIDG
arguments.description: Specifies the Newton-Raphson Ridge method.

arguments.name: QUANEW
arguments.description: Specifies the quasi-Newton method.

arguments.name: TRUREG
arguments.description: Specifies the trust region method.

arguments.name: NOPRINT
arguments.description: Suppresses all printed output.

arguments.name: PRINTALL
arguments.description: Requests all printing options.

arguments.name: PRINTINTERNALNAMES
arguments.description: Prints internal names assigned to parameters.

arguments.name: PRINTTIMING
arguments.description: Prints a timing report.

arguments.name: STORE=
arguments.description: Specifies the item store that preserves the properties of the model and the fit results. No information pertaining to the model is preserved unless this option is specified.

statements.name: BOUNDS
statements.description: The BOUNDS statement imposes simple boundary constraints on the parameter estimates. You can specify any number of BOUNDS statements. Each bound is composed of parameters, constants, and inequality operators: tem operator item [ operator item [ operator item …] ] Each item is a constant, parameter, or list of parameters. Parameters associated with a regressor variable are referred to by the name of the corresponding regressor variable. Each operator is ’<’, ’>’, ’≤’, or ’≥’.

statements.name: BY
statements.description: A BY statement can be used with PROC CNTSELECT to obtain separate analyses on observations in groups defined by the BY variables. When a BY statement appears, the input data set should be sorted in order of the BY variables.

statements.name: CLASS
statements.description: The CLASS statement names the classification variables to be used as explanatory variables in the analysis. The CLASS statement must precede the MODEL statement.

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: Reverses the sort order of the classification variable. If both the DESCENDING and ORDER= options are specified, PROC BCHOICE orders the categories according to the ORDER= option and then reverses that order.

arguments.name: MISSING
arguments.description: Treats missing values (., ._, .A, …, .Z for numeric variables and blanks for character variables) as valid values for the CLASS variable.

arguments.name: ORDER=
arguments.description: Specifies the sort order for the levels of classification variables. This ordering determines which parameters in the model correspond to each level in the data. By default, ORDER=FORMATTED. For ORDER=FORMATTED and ORDER=INTERNAL, the sort order is machine-dependent. When ORDER=FORMATTED is in effect for numeric variables for which you have supplied no explicit format, the levels are ordered by their internal values.

arguments.name: FORMATTED
arguments.description: Levels sorted by the external formatted value, except for numeric variables with no explicit format, which are sorted by their unformatted (internal) value.

arguments.name: FREQ
arguments.description: Levels sorted by the descending frequency count (levels that have more observations come ealier in the order).

arguments.name: INTERNAL
arguments.description: Levels sorted by the unformatted value. The sort order is machine-dependent.

arguments.name: PARAM=
arguments.description: Specifies the parameterization method for the classification variable or variables.
arguments.help: PARAM=EFFECT | GLM | ORDINAL | POLYNOMIAL | REFERENCE | ORTHEFFECT | ORTHORDINAL | ORTHPOLY | ORTHREF

arguments.name: EFFECT
arguments.description: Specifies effect coding.

arguments.name: GLM
arguments.description: Specifies less-than-full-rank, reference-cell coding; this option can be used only as a global option.

arguments.name: ORDINAL
arguments.description: Specifies the cumulative parameterization for an ordinal CLASS variable.

arguments.name: POLYNOMIAL
arguments.description: Specifies polynomial coding.

arguments.name: REFERENCE
arguments.description: Specifies reference-cell coding.

arguments.name: ORTHEFFECT
arguments.description: Orthogonalizes PARAM=EFFECT.

arguments.name: ORTHORDINAL
arguments.description: Orthogonalizes PARAM=ORDINAL.

arguments.name: ORTHPOLY
arguments.description: Orthogonalizes PARAM=POLYNOMIAL.

arguments.name: ORTHREF
arguments.description: Orthogonalizes PARAM=REFERENCE.

arguments.name: REFERENCE=
arguments.description: Specifies the reference level that is used when you specify a nonsingular parameterization.
Specifies the level of the variable to use as the reference level. Specify the formatted value of the variable if a format is assigned. Replace <level> with an actual value.

arguments.name: FIRST
arguments.description: Designates the first ordered level as reference.

arguments.name: LAST
arguments.description: Designates the last ordered level as reference.

arguments.name: SPLIT
arguments.description: Specifies that design matrix columns that correspond to any effect that contains a split classification variable can be selected to enter or leave a model independently of the other design columns of that effect.

statements.name: DISPLAY
statements.description: The DISPLAY statement enables you to specify a list of display tables to display or exclude. This statement is similar to the ODS SELECT, ODS EXCLUDE, and ODS TRACE statements. However, the DISPLAY statement can improve performance when a large number of tables could be generated (such as in BY-group processing). The procedure processes the DISPLAY statement on a CAS server and thus sends only a subset of ODS tables to the SAS client. Because ODS statements are processed on a SAS client, all the display tables generated are first sent to the client and then the client creates a subset. If both DISPLAY and ODS statements are used together, the DISPLAY statement takes precedence over the ODS statements.

arguments.name: CASESENSITIVE
arguments.description: Performs a case-sensitive comparison of table names in the table-list to display table names when tables are subsetted for display. To preserve case, you must enclose table names in the table-list in quotation marks.

arguments.name: EXCLUDE
arguments.description: Displays all display tables except those specified in the table-list.

arguments.name: EXCLUDEALL
arguments.description: Suppresses display of all tables. This option takes precedence over the other options.

arguments.name: TRACE
arguments.description: Displays the display table names, labels, and paths.

statements.name: DISPLAYOUT
statements.description: The DISPLAYOUT statement enables you to create CAS output tables from your displayed output. This statement is similar to the ODS OUTPUT statement. The table-spec-list specifies a list of CAS output tables to create. Each entry in the list has either a key or a key=value format: key=value specifies key as the ODS table name, path, or partial pathname, and specifies value as the CAS output table name. key specifies key as the ODS table name and also as the CAS output table name. Table names and partial pathnames are discussed under the DISPLAY statement. The DISPLAYOUT statement does not support regular expressions.

arguments.name: INCLUDEALL
arguments.description: Creates output CAS tables for all display tables. The name of the created output CAS table is the same as the corresponding display table name. If you specify this option, the table-spec-list specification is ignored.

arguments.name: NOREPLACE
arguments.description: Does not replace an existing CAS output table of the same name.

arguments.name: REPEATED
arguments.description: Replicates the CAS output tables on all nodes.

statements.name: DISPMODEL
statements.description: The DISPMODEL statement specifies the dispersion-related-regressors that are used to model dispersion. This statement is ignored unless you specify either DIST=CMPOISSON or DIST=ZICMPOISSON in the MODEL statement. The dependent-variable in the DISPMODEL statement must be the same as the dependent-variable in the MODEL statement.

statements.name: EFFECT
statements.description: The EFFECT statement enables you to construct special collections of columns for design matrices. These collections are referred to as constructed effects to distinguish them from the usual model effects that are formed from continuous or classification variables.

arguments.name: NAME=
arguments.description: Replace ‘NAME’ with the name of the effect, specified after the EFFECT keyword. This name can appear in only one EFFECT statement and cannot be the name of a variable in the input data set. These values can be used: COLLECTION, MULTIMEMBER, POLYNOMIAL, or SPLINE.

arguments.name: BASIS=
arguments.description: [For the SPLINE effect-type only] Specifies a basis for the spline expansion.

arguments.name: BSPLINE
arguments.description: Specifies a B-spline basis for the spline expansion.

arguments.name: TPF
arguments.description: Syntax: TPF(options) Specifies a truncated power function basis for the spline expansion. You can modify the number of columns when you request BASIS=TPF with the following options: NOINT excludes the intercept column. NOPOWERS excludes the intercept and polynomial columns.

arguments.name: DATABOUNDARY
arguments.description: [For the SPLINE effect-type only] Specifies that the extremes of the data be used as boundary knots when building a B-spline basis.

arguments.name: DETAILS
arguments.description: [For the COLLECTION | MULTIMEMBER | POLYNOMIAL |SPLINE effect-type] Requests a table that shows the: (1) constituents of the collection effect, or (2) levels of the multimember effect, or (3) details of the specified polynomial, or (4) knot locations and the knots associated with each spline basis function.

arguments.name: KNOTMETHOD=
arguments.description: [For the SPLINE effect-type only] Specifies how to construct the knots for spline effects.
arguments.help: KNOTMETHOD=EQUAL | LIST | LISTWITHBOUNDARY | MULTISCALE | PERCENTILES | RANGEFRACTIONS

arguments.name: EQUAL
arguments.description: Syntax: EQUAL<(n)> Specifies that n equally spaced knots be positioned between the extremes of the data. The default is n=3. For a B-spline basis, any needed boundary knots continue to be equally spaced unless the DATABOUNDARY option has also been specified. KNOTMETHOD=EQUAL is the default if no knot-method is specified.

arguments.name: LIST
arguments.description: Syntax: LIST(number-list) Specifies the list of internal knots to be used in forming the spline basis columns. For a B-spline basis, the data extremes are used as boundary knots.

arguments.name: LISTWITHBOUNDARY
arguments.description: Syntax: LISTWITHBOUNDARY(number-list) Specifies the list of all knots that are used in forming the spline basis columns.

arguments.name: MULTISCALE
arguments.description: Syntax: MULTISCALE<(multiscale-options)> Specifies that multiple B-spline bases be generated, corresponding to sets with an increasing number of internal knots. You can control which scales are included with the following multiscale-options: STARTSCALE=n specifies the start scale, where n is a positive integer. The default is STARTSCALE=0. ENDSCALE=n specifies the end scale, where n is a positive integer. The default is ENDSCALE=7.

arguments.name: PERCENTILES
arguments.description: Syntax: PERCENTILES(n) Requests that internal knots be placed at n equally spaced percentiles of the variable or variables named in the EFFECT statement.

arguments.name: RANGEFRACTIONS
arguments.description: Syntax: RANGEFRACTIONS(fraction-list) Requests that internal knots be placed at each fraction of the ranges of the variables in the EFFECT statement.

arguments.name: NATURALCUBIC
arguments.description: [For the SPLINE effect-type only] Uses a natural cubic spline basis for the spline expansion. Natural cubic splines, also known as restricted cubic splines, are cubic splines that are constrained to be linear beyond the extreme knots.

arguments.name: NOEFFECT
arguments.description: [For the MULTIMEMBER effect-type only] Specifies that observations whose levels are all missing for the multimember variables should have 0 values in the corresponding design matrix columns.

arguments.name: NOSEPARATE
arguments.description: [For the POLYNOMIAL effect-type only] Specifies that the polynomial be treated as a single effect with multiple degrees of freedom. The effect name that you specify is used as the constructed effect name, and the labels of the terms are used as labels of the corresponding parameters.

arguments.name: SEPARATE
arguments.description: [For the SPLINE effect-type only] Specifies that when multiple variables are specified in the EFFECT statement, the spline basis for each variable be treated as a separate effect. The names of these separated effects are formed by appending an underscore followed by the name of the variable to the name that you specify in the EFFECT statement.

arguments.name: SPLIT
arguments.description: [For the SPLINE effect-type only] Specifies that each individual column in the design matrix that corresponds to the spline effect be treated as a separate effect that can enter or leave the model independently. Names for these split effects are generated by appending the variable name and an index for each column to the name that you specify in the EFFECT statement.

arguments.name: STANDARDIZE
arguments.description: Specifies that the variables that define the polynomial be standardized. By default, the standardized variables receive prefix "s_" in the variable names. You can use the following centerscale-opts to specify how the center and scale are estimated: METHOD=MOMENTS specifies that the center be estimated by the variable mean and the scale be estimated by the standard deviation. METHOD=RANGE specifies that the center be estimated by the midpoint of the variable range and the scale be estimated as half the variable range. METHOD=WMOMENTS is the same as METHOD=MOMENTS except that weighted means and weighted standard deviations are used.

arguments.name: CENTER
arguments.description: Specifies that variables be centered but not scaled.

arguments.name: CENTERSCALE
arguments.description: Specifies that variables be centered and scaled. This is the default if you do not specify a standardization-opt.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Specifies that no standardization be performed.

arguments.name: SCALE
arguments.description: Specifies that variables be scaled but not centered.

arguments.name: STDIZE
arguments.description: [For the MULTIMEMBER effect-type only] Specifies that for each observation, the entries in the design matrix that corresponds to the multimember effect be scaled to have a sum of one.

statements.name: FREQ
statements.description: The FREQ statement identifies a variable (freq-variable) that contains the frequency of occurrence of each observation. PROC CNTSELECT treats each observation as if it appears n times, where n is the value of freq-variable for the observation. If the value for the observation is not an integer, it is truncated to an integer. If the value is less than 1 or missing, the observation is not used in the model fitting. When the FREQ statement is not specified, each observation is assigned a frequency of 1.

statements.name: INIT
statements.description: The INIT statement sets initial values for parameters in the optimization. Each initialization is written as a parameter or parameter list, followed by an optional equal sign (=), followed by a number: parameter <=> number

statements.name: MODEL
statements.description: The MODEL statement specifies the dependent variable and independent regressor variables for the regression model. The dependent count variable should take only nonnegative integer values from the input data set. PROC CNTSELECT rounds any positive noninteger count value to the nearest integer. PROC CNTSELECT discards any observation that has a negative count.

arguments.name: CORRB
arguments.description: Prints the correlation matrix of the parameter estimates.

arguments.name: COVB
arguments.description: Prints the covariance matrix of the parameter estimates.

arguments.name: DIST=
arguments.description: Specifies a type of model to be analyzed.
arguments.help: DIST=POISSON | CMPOISSON | NEGBIN(P=1) | NEGBIN(P=2) | ZIPOISSON | ZICMPOISSON | ZINEGBIN

arguments.name: POISSON
arguments.description: Specifies the Poisson regression model.

arguments.name: CMPOISSON
arguments.description: Specifies a Conway-Maxwell-Poisson regression model.

arguments.name: NEGBIN(P=1)
arguments.description: Specifies the negative binomial regression model that uses a linear variance function.

arguments.name: NEGBIN(P=2)
arguments.description: Specifies the negative binomial regression model that users a quadratic variance function.

arguments.name: ZIPOISSON
arguments.description: Specifies the zero-inflated Poisson regression.

arguments.name: ZICMPOISSON
arguments.description: Specifies a zero-inflated Conway-Maxwell-Poisson regression. The ZEROMODEL statement must be specified when this model type is specified.

arguments.name: ZINEGBIN
arguments.description: Specifies the zero-inflated negative binomial regression

arguments.name: ERRORCOMP=
arguments.description: Specifies a type of conditional panel model to be analyzed.

arguments.name: FIXED
arguments.description: Specifies a fixed-effect error component regression model.

arguments.name: RANDOM
arguments.description: Specifies a random-effect error component regression model.

arguments.name: NOINT
arguments.description: Suppresses the intercept parameter.

arguments.name: NOPRINT
arguments.description: Suppresses all printed output.

arguments.name: OFFSET=
arguments.description: Specifies a variable in the input data set to be used as an offset variable. The offset-variable is used to allow the observational units to vary across observations.

arguments.name: PARAMETER=
arguments.description: Specifies the parameterization for the Conway-Maxwell-Poisson model. By default, PARAMETER=MU.

arguments.name: MU
arguments.description: Reparameterizes λ as documented by Guikema and Coffelt (2008).

arguments.name: LAMDA
arguments.description: Estimates the original Conway-Maxwell-Poisson model (Shmueli et al. 2005).

arguments.name: PRINTALL
arguments.description: Requests all printing options.

statements.name: OUTPUT
statements.description: The OUTPUT statement creates a new SAS data set that includes variables created by the output-options.

arguments.name: COPYVAR=
arguments.description: Adds SAS variables to the output data set.

arguments.name: DISPERSION=
arguments.description: Assigns a name to the variable that contains the value of dispersion for the Conway-Maxwell-Poisson distribution.

arguments.name: GDELTA=
arguments.description: Assigns a name to the variable that contains estimates of gi'δ for the Conway-Maxwell-Poisson distribution.

arguments.name: LAMBDA=
arguments.description: Assigns a name to the variable that contains the estimate of λ for the Conway-Maxwell-Poisson distribution.

arguments.name: MODE=
arguments.description: Assigns a name to the variable that contains the integral part of µ(mode) for the Conway-Maxwell-Poisson distribution.

arguments.name: MU=
arguments.description: Assigns a name to the variable that contains the estimate of µ for the Conway-Maxwell-Poisson distribution.

arguments.name: NU=
arguments.description: Assigns a name to the variable that contains the estimate of ν for the Conway-Maxwell-Poisson distribution.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: Names the output data set.

arguments.name: PRED=
arguments.description: Names the variable to contain the predicted value of the response variable.

arguments.name: PROB=
arguments.description: Names the variable to contain the probability that the response variable will take the actual value, Pr(Y=yi).

arguments.name: PROBCOUNT
arguments.description: Outputs the probability that the response variable will take particular values. Each value should be a nonnegative integer. If you specify a noninteger, it is rounded to the nearest integer.

arguments.name: PROBZERO=
arguments.description: Names the variable to contain the value that of Φ, which is the probability that the response variable will take the value of zero as a result of the zero-generating process. This variable is written to the output file only if the model is zero-inflated.

arguments.name: VARIANCE=
arguments.description: Assigns a name to the variable that contains the estimate of variance for the Conway-Maxwell-Poisson distribution.

arguments.name: XBETA=
arguments.description: Names the variable to contain estimates of x'β.

arguments.name: ZGAMMA=
arguments.description: Names the variable to contain estimates of z'Gamma.

statements.name: RESTRICT
statements.description: The RESTRICT statement imposes linear restrictions on the parameter estimates. You can specify any number of RESTRICT statements. Each restriction is written as an expression, followed by an equality operator (=) or an inequality operator (<, >, ≤, ≥ ), followed by a second expression: expression operator expression The operator can be =, <, >, ≤, or ≥ . A restriction expression is composed of parameter names, constants, and the operators times (*), plus (+), and minus (-). Each restriction expression must be a linear function of the parameters in the model.

statements.name: SELECTION
statements.description: The SELECTION statement performs model selection by examining whether effects should be added to or removed from the model according to rules that are defined by the selection methods.

arguments.name: DETAILS=
arguments.description: Specifies the level of detail to be produced about the selection process. The default is DETAILS=SUMMARY.

arguments.name: SUMMARY
arguments.description: Produces only the selection summary, stop reason, selection reason, and selected effects tables.

arguments.name: STEPS
arguments.description: Produces the preceding summary table and displays the results from fitting each model at each step.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Produces the preceding tables and a detailed listing of all candidates at each step along with their ranking in terms of the selection criterion for addition to or removal from the model.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Specicies no details.

arguments.name: METHOD=
arguments.description: Specifies the selection method to use.

arguments.name: BACKWARD
arguments.description: Specifies the backward elimination method.

arguments.name: FORWARD
arguments.description: Specifies the forward selection method.

arguments.name: FORWARDSWAP
arguments.description: Specifies forward-swap selection, which is an extension of the forward selection method.

arguments.name: STEPWISE
arguments.description: Specifies the stepwise regression method.

arguments.name: STOPHORIZON=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of consecutive steps at which the STOP= criterion must worsen in order for a local extremum to be detected. The stop horizon value is ignored if you also specify STOP=NONE or STOP=SL. For example, suppose that STOP=AIC and the sequence of AIC values at steps 1 to 6 of a selection are 10, 7, 4, 6, 5, 2. If STOPHORIZON=2, then the AIC criterion is deemed to have a local minimum at step 3 because the AIC value at the next two steps are greater than the value 4 that occurs at step 3. However, if STOPHORIZON=3, then the value at step 3 is not deemed to be a local minimum because the AIC value at step 6 is lower than the AIC value at step 3. When METHOD=LAR or METHOD=LASSO, n is ignored and STOPHORIZON=1 is used. By default, STOPHORIZON=3.

statements.name: TEST
statements.description: The TEST statement performs Wald, Lagrange multiplier, and likelihood ratio tests of linear hypotheses about the regression parameters that are specified in the preceding MODEL statement. Each test is written either as a single linear equation or as a comma-separated list of two or more linear equations. A test equation specifies a linear hypothesis to be tested and consists of an expression, followed by the equality operator (=), followed by a second expression: expression = expression The rules governing valid test expressions are the same as those for restriction expressions.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Requests Wald, Lagrange multiplier, and likelihood ratio tests.

arguments.name: LM
arguments.description: Requests the Lagrange multiplier test.

arguments.name: LR
arguments.description: Requests the likelihood ratio test.

arguments.name: WALD
arguments.description: Requests the Wald test.

statements.name: VIEWSTORE
statements.description: The VIEWSTORE statement allows you to print various reports that describe the model fitting information which is preserved in an item store. The item store must have been created using the STORE= option in the FIT statement.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: When this option is provided, the entire contents of the item store are printed.

arguments.name: BYVARVALUES
arguments.description: When this option is provided, the values of the BY-Group variables that were used to fit the model are printed.

arguments.name: CLASSVARLEVELS
arguments.description: When this option is provided, the classification variables and levels that were used in the model are printed.

arguments.name: CORRELATIONS
arguments.description: When this option is provided, the correlation matrices are printed.

arguments.name: COVARIANCES
arguments.description: When this option is provided, the covariance matrix is printed.

arguments.name: FINALESTIMATES
arguments.description: When this option is provided, the Final Parameter Estimates are printed.

arguments.name: FITMODELSUMMARY
arguments.description: When this option is provided, the Fit Model Summary is printed.

arguments.name: INITIALESTIMATES
arguments.description: When this option is provided, the Initial Parameter Estimates are printed.

arguments.name: INSTORE=
arguments.description: Specifies the item store that you want to view.

arguments.name: MINIMAL
arguments.description: When this option is provided, only the Fit Model Summary and Final Parameter Estimates are printed.

arguments.name: MODELDEFINITION
arguments.description: When this option is provided, the statements that defined the model are printed.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: When this option is provided, no reports are printed.

arguments.name: OPTIMIZERSETTINGS
arguments.description: When this option is provided, the optimizer settings that were used to fit the model are printed.

statements.name: WEIGHT
statements.description: The WEIGHT statement specifies a variable to supply weighting values to use for each observation in estimating parameters. The log likelihood for each observation is multiplied by the corresponding weight variable value.

arguments.name: NONORMALIZE
arguments.description: Does not normalize the weights.

statements.name: ZEROMODEL
statements.description: The ZEROMODEL statement is required if either ZIP or ZINB is specified in the DIST= option in the MODEL statement. If ZIP or ZINB is specified, then the ZEROMODEL statement must follow immediately after the MODEL statement. The dependent variable in the ZEROMODEL statement must be the same as the dependent variable in the MODEL statement. The zero-inflated (ZI) regressors appear in the equation that determines the probability of a zero count.

arguments.name: LINK=
arguments.description: Specifies the distribution function used to compute probability of zeros.

arguments.name: LOGISTIC
arguments.description: Specifies logistic distribution.

arguments.name: NORMAL
arguments.description: Specifies standard normal distribution.

arguments.name: OFFSET=
arguments.description: Specifies a variable in the input data set to be used as a zero-inflated (ZI) offset variable.
